Casimir effect for the Higgs field at finite temperature
A. F. Santos
Instituto de Física, Universidade Federal de Mato Grosso,
78060-900, Cuiabá, Mato Grosso, Brazil
alesandroferreira@fisica.ufmt.br
Faqir C. Khanna *
Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Victoria,
3800 Finnerty Road Victoria, BC, Canada
khannaf@uvic.ca
Received 14 July 2017
Accepted 21 July 2017
Published 4 August 2017
In early 1970, it was postulated that there exists a zero spin quantum field, called Higgs
field, that is present in all universe. The potential energy of the Higgs field is transferred
to particles. Hence they acquire mass. These ideas were essential in fulfilling the basic
need for a particle, called Higgs, with mass. These particles are called Higgs particles
with spin zero with its mass to be ∼ 125 GeV. This raises the question as to its physical
effects. If these particles are present, will they exhibit a Casimir effect and also obey the
Stefan-Boltzmann Law? Assuming the dynamics of this field, will these effects change
with temperature. The present calculation uses thermo field dynamics formalism to
calculate temperature effects.
Keywords: Casimir effect; Higgs field; finite temperature.
PACS numbers: 03.65.−w, 11.10.Wx
text.body:
1. Introduction
The Standard Model provides a framework for our present understanding of forces of
nature and fundamental particles. This model describes three types of forces: weak,
electromagnetic and strong nuclear. In 1970s, weak and electromagnetic interactions
were unified as the electroweak force. The weak force describes interaction of elec-
trons, neutrinos, quarks and other particles with exchange of W and Z particles.

text.body:
Electromagnetism describes interaction of charged particles with exchange of pho-
tons. The photon is massless while W and Z have mass, nearly 100 times that of a
proton. To solve this problem the Higgs mechanism was proposed. 1-6 This mecha-
nism gives a mass to the W and Z particles when they interact with the Higgs field.
The potential energy of the Higgs field is transferred to particles that leads to the
Higgs boson that is uncharged, even parity and zero spin, which has been observed
at LHC. 7,8 There are speculations that a charged Higgs particle may exist. However,
this has not been established yet. Will Higgs particles with spin zero and no charge
display properties similar to those of other fundamental particles? It is well known
that the Casimir effect is a phenomenon observed for the electromagnetic field. Is
there a Casimir effect due to the presence of the Higgs field? Since it has a quantum
nature, it is expected to show Casimir force and the Stefan-Boltzmann effect.
The Casimir effect 9 has been measured when two parallel conducting plates
are attracted due to vacuum fluctuations of the electromagnetic field. The first
experimental to observe the Casimir effect was made by Sparnaay. 10 Now this effect
has been established to a high degree of accuracy for the electromagnetic field. 11,12
There are some practical applications, such as, micro-and nanotechnologies 13,14
and superconductors at high temperature. 15,16 Finite temperature corrections to
the Casimir effect involving the electromagnetic field have been calculated. 17 Our
objective in this paper is to calculate the Casimir effect for the Higgs particles.
Studies at zero temperature on this issue has been carried out. 18 However, what is
the effect of temperature for the Higgs particles? The thermo field dynamics (TFD)
formalism is used to find the finite temperature effect on both the Casimir effect as
well as on the Stefan-Boltzmann effect.
TFD 19-24 is a thermal quantum field theory. In this formalism, the statistical
average of an arbitrary operator is interpreted as an expectation value in a thermal
vacuum, i.e. A = 0(β)|A|0(β). The thermal vacuum, defined by |0(β), describes
a system in thermal equilibrium, where β = 1
kB T , with T is the temperature and
k B is the Boltzmann constant (we use k B = 1). This formalism is composed of two
elements: (i) doubling, tilde and nontilde components, of the original Hilbert space
and (ii) using the Bogoliubov transformation of the Hilbert space. Bogoliubov trans-
formation introduces a rotation in the tilde and nontilde operators. The physical
quantities are described by nontilde operators.
This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. 2, a brief introduction to the TFD
formalism is presented. In Sec. 3, the Higgs field Lagrangian is given. The energy-
momentum tensor is calculated. In Sec. 4, some applications are developed. The
Stefan-Boltzmann law and the Casimir effect for the Higgs field at zero and finite
temperature are calculated. In Sec. 5, some concluding remarks are presented.

5. Conclusions
The Higgs field is present everywhere in the universe. The interaction of this funda-
mental field with any particle results in the appearance of mass through the Higgs
mechanism and the spontaneous symmetry breaking. Although Higgs boson has
been observed experimentally, there remains several other questions with regards
to the presence of charged Higgs bosons. This brings to the possibility to observe
the Casimir effect. The Higgs field is present since the beginning of the universe, this
must have other implications for particle physics and how the finite temperature
effects may modify the Casimir effect? The Stefan-Boltzmann law and the Casimir
effect for the Higgs field at zero and finite temperature are calculated. Experiments
are likely to confirm some of these results.
